an11.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an11.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an11.1:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an11.1:1.3.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an11.1:1.4.eng: “Sir, what is the purpose and benefit of skillful ethics?”

an11.1:1.5.eng: “Ānanda, having no regrets is the purpose and benefit of skillful ethics.”

an11.1:2.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of having no regrets?”

an11.1:2.2.eng: “Joy is the purpose and benefit of having no regrets.”

an11.1:3.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of joy?”

an11.1:4.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of rapture?”

an11.1:5.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of tranquility?”

an11.1:6.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of bliss?”

an11.1:7.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of immersion?”

an11.1:8.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of truly knowing and seeing?”

an11.1:9.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of disillusionment?”

an11.1:10.1.eng: “But what is the purpose and benefit of dispassion?”

an11.1:10.2.eng: “Knowledge and vision of freedom is the purpose and benefit of dispassion.

an11.1:11.1.pli: Iti kho, ānanda, kusalāni sīlāni avippaṭisāratthāni avippaṭisārānisaṃsāni,
an11.1:11.1.eng: So, Ānanda, the purpose and benefit of skillful ethics is not having regrets.

an11.1:11.2.eng: Joy is the purpose and benefit of not having regrets.

an11.1:11.3.eng: Rapture is the purpose and benefit of joy.

an11.1:11.4.eng: Tranquility is the purpose and benefit of rapture.

an11.1:11.5.eng: Bliss is the purpose and benefit of tranquility.

an11.1:11.6.eng: Immersion is the purpose and benefit of bliss.

an11.1:11.7.eng: Truly knowing and seeing is the purpose and benefit of immersion.

an11.1:11.8.eng: Disillusionment is the purpose and benefit of truly knowing and seeing.

an11.1:11.9.eng: Dispassion is the purpose and benefit of disillusionment.

an11.1:11.10.eng: And knowledge and vision of freedom is the purpose and benefit of dispassion.

an11.1:11.11.pli: Iti kho, ānanda, kusalāni sīlāni anupubbena aggāya parentī”ti.
an11.1:11.11.eng: So, Ānanda, skillful ethics progressively lead up to the highest.”

an11.10:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati moranivāpe paribbājakārāme.
an11.10:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, at the monastery of the wanderers in the peacocks’ feeding ground.

an11.10:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an11.10:2.1.pli: “Tīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu accantaniṭṭho hoti accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānaṃ.
an11.10:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant who has three qualities has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal. They are best among gods and humans.

an11.10:2.3.pli: Asekhena sīlakkhandhena, asekhena samādhikkhandhena, asekhena paññākkhandhena—
an11.10:2.3.eng: The entire spectrum of an adept’s ethics, immersion, and wisdom.

an11.10:2.4.pli: imehi, kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu accantaniṭṭho hoti accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānaṃ.
an11.10:2.4.eng: A mendicant with these three qualities has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal. They are best among gods and humans.

an11.10:3.1.pli: Aparehipi, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu accantaniṭṭho hoti accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānaṃ.
an11.10:3.1.eng: A mendicant who has another three qualities has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal. They are best among gods and humans.

an11.10:3.3.eng: A demonstration of psychic power, a demonstration of revealing, and a demonstration of instruction.

an11.10:3.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu accantaniṭṭho hoti, accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānaṃ.
an11.10:3.4.eng: A mendicant with these three qualities has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal. They are best among gods and humans.

an11.10:4.1.pli: Aparehipi, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu accantaniṭṭho hoti accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānaṃ.
an11.10:4.1.eng: A mendicant who has another three qualities has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal. They are best among gods and humans.

an11.10:4.3.eng: Right view, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an11.10:4.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu accantaniṭṭho hoti accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānaṃ.
an11.10:4.4.eng: A mendicant with these three qualities has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal. They are best among gods and humans.

an11.10:5.1.pli: Dvīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu accantaniṭṭho hoti accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānaṃ.
an11.10:5.1.eng: A mendicant who has two qualities has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal. They are best among gods and humans.

an11.10:5.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, dvīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu accantaniṭṭho hoti accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānaṃ.
an11.10:5.4.eng: A mendicant with these two qualities has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal. They are best among gods and humans.

an11.10:5.5.pli: Brahmunā pesā, bhikkhave, sanaṅkumārena gāthā bhāsitā:
an11.10:5.5.eng: The divinity Sanaṅkumāra also spoke this verse:

an11.10:6.2.eng: who take clan as the standard.

an11.10:6.3.eng: But one accomplished in knowledge and conduct

an11.10:6.4.eng: is first among gods and humans.’

an11.10:7.1.pli: Sā kho panesā, bhikkhave, sanaṅkumārena gāthā bhāsitā subhāsitā, no dubbhāsitā; atthasaṃhitā, no anatthasaṃhitā; anumatā mayā.
an11.10:7.1.eng: Now, that verse spoken by the divinity Sanaṅkumāra is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s beneficial, not pointless, and I agree with it.

an11.10:8.2.eng: who take clan as the standard.

an11.10:8.3.eng: But one accomplished in knowledge and conduct

an11.10:8.4.eng: is first among gods and humans.’”

an11.11:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
an11.11:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

an11.11:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū bhagavato cīvarakammaṃ karonti:
an11.11:1.2.eng: At that time several mendicants were making a robe for the Buddha, thinking that

an11.11:1.3.eng: when his robe was finished and the three months of the rains residence had passed the Buddha would set out wandering.

an11.11:1.4.eng: Mahānāma the Sakyan heard about this.

an11.11:2.1.pli: Atha kho mahānāmo sakko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho mahānāmo sakko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an11.11:2.1.eng: He went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an11.11:2.3.eng: several mendicants are making a robe for the Buddha, thinking that

an11.11:2.4.eng: when his robe was finished and the three months of the rains residence had passed the Buddha would set out wandering.

an11.11:2.5.pli: Tesaṃ no, bhante, nānāvihārehi viharataṃ kenassa vihārena vihātabban”ti?
an11.11:2.5.eng: Now, we spend our life in various ways. Which of these should we practice?”

an11.11:3.2.pli: Etaṃ kho, mahānāma, tumhākaṃ patirūpaṃ kulaputtānaṃ, yaṃ tumhe tathāgataṃ upasaṅkamitvā puccheyyātha:
an11.11:3.2.eng: It’s appropriate that gentlemen such as you come to me and ask:

an11.11:3.3.pli: ‘tesaṃ no, bhante, nānāvihārehi viharataṃ kenassa vihārena vihātabban’ti?
an11.11:3.3.eng: ‘We spend our life in various ways. Which of these should we practice?’

an11.11:3.4.pli: Saddho kho, mahānāma, ārādhako hoti, no assaddho;
an11.11:3.4.eng: The faithful succeed, not the faithless.

an11.11:3.5.eng: The energetic succeed, not the lazy.

an11.11:3.6.eng: The mindful succeed, not the unmindful.

an11.11:3.7.eng: Those with immersion succeed, not those without immersion.

an11.11:3.8.eng: The wise succeed, not the witless.

an11.11:3.9.pli: Imesu kho tvaṃ, mahānāma, pañcasu dhammesu patiṭṭhāya cha dhamme uttari bhāveyyāsi.
an11.11:3.9.eng: When you’re grounded on these five things, go on to develop six further things.

an11.11:3.10.eng: Firstly, you should recollect the Realized One:

an11.11:3.11.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
an11.11:3.11.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

an11.11:3.12.pli: Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako tathāgataṃ anussarati, nevassa tasmiṃ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti;
an11.11:3.12.eng: When a noble disciple recollects the Realized One their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion.

an11.11:3.13.pli: ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hoti tathāgataṃ ārabbha.
an11.11:3.13.eng: At that time their mind is quite unswerving, based on the Realized One.

an11.11:3.14.pli: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.
an11.11:3.14.eng: A noble disciple whose mind is unswerving finds inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and finds joy connected with the teaching.

an11.11:3.15.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
an11.11:3.15.eng: When they’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when they’re blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

an11.11:3.16.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, mahānāma, ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotasamāpanno buddhānussatiṃ bhāveti.
an11.11:3.16.eng: This is called a noble disciple who lives in balance among people who are unbalanced, and lives untroubled among people who are troubled. They’ve entered the stream of the teaching and developed the recollection of the Buddha.

an11.11:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ tvaṃ, mahānāma, dhammaṃ anussareyyāsi:
an11.11:4.1.eng: Furthermore, you should recollect the teaching:

an11.11:4.2.pli: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī’ti.
an11.11:4.2.eng: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’

an11.11:4.3.pli: Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako dhammaṃ anussarati, nevassa tasmiṃ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti;
an11.11:4.3.eng: When a noble disciple recollects the teaching their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion. …

an11.11:4.4.pli: ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hoti dhammaṃ ārabbha.

an11.11:4.5.pli: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.

an11.11:4.6.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.

an11.11:4.7.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, mahānāma, ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotasamāpanno dhammānussatiṃ bhāveti.
an11.11:4.7.eng: This is called a noble disciple who lives in balance among people who are unbalanced, and lives untroubled among people who are troubled. They’ve entered the stream of the teaching and developed the recollection of the teaching.

an11.11:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ tvaṃ, mahānāma, saṅghaṃ anussareyyāsi:
an11.11:5.1.eng: Furthermore, you should recollect the Saṅgha:

an11.11:5.2.pli: ‘suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ujuppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ñāyappaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, sāmīcippaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, yadidaṃ cattāri purisayugāni aṭṭha purisapuggalā, esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā’ti.
an11.11:5.2.eng: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.’

an11.11:5.3.pli: Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako saṅghaṃ anussarati, nevassa tasmiṃ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti;
an11.11:5.3.eng: When a noble disciple recollects the Saṅgha their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion. …

an11.11:5.4.pli: ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hoti saṅghaṃ ārabbha.

an11.11:5.5.pli: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.

an11.11:5.6.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.

an11.11:5.7.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, mahānāma, ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotasamāpanno saṅghānussatiṃ bhāveti.
an11.11:5.7.eng: This is called a noble disciple who lives in balance among people who are unbalanced, and lives untroubled among people who are troubled. They’ve entered the stream of the teaching and developed the recollection of the Saṅgha.

an11.11:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ tvaṃ, mahānāma, attano sīlāni anussareyyāsi akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṃvattanikāni.
an11.11:6.1.eng: Furthermore, you should recollect your own ethical conduct, which is intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.

an11.11:6.2.pli: Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako sīlaṃ anussarati, nevassa tasmiṃ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti;
an11.11:6.2.eng: When a noble disciple recollects their ethical conduct their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion. …

an11.11:6.3.pli: ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hoti sīlaṃ ārabbha.

an11.11:6.4.pli: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.

an11.11:6.5.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.

an11.11:6.6.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, mahānāma, ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotasamāpanno sīlānussatiṃ bhāveti.
an11.11:6.6.eng: This is called a noble disciple who lives in balance among people who are unbalanced, and lives untroubled among people who are troubled. They’ve entered the stream of the teaching and developed the recollection of their ethical conduct.

an11.11:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ tvaṃ, mahānāma, attano cāgaṃ anussareyyāsi:
an11.11:7.1.eng: Furthermore, you should recollect your own generosity:

an11.11:7.3.pli: yohaṃ maccheramalapariyuṭṭhitāya pajāya vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasāmi muttacāgo payatapāṇi vossaggarato yācayogo dānasaṃvibhāgarato’ti.
an11.11:7.3.eng: Among people with hearts full of the stain of stinginess I live at home rid of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.’

an11.11:7.4.pli: Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako cāgaṃ anussarati, nevassa tasmiṃ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti;
an11.11:7.4.eng: When a noble disciple recollects their own generosity their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion. …

an11.11:7.5.pli: ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hoti cāgaṃ ārabbha.

an11.11:7.6.pli: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.

an11.11:7.7.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.

an11.11:7.8.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, mahānāma, ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotasamāpanno cāgānussatiṃ bhāveti.
an11.11:7.8.eng: This is called a noble disciple who lives in balance among people who are unbalanced, and lives untroubled among people who are troubled. They’ve entered the stream of the teaching and developed the recollection of generosity.

an11.11:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ tvaṃ, mahānāma, devatā anussareyyāsi:
an11.11:8.1.eng: Furthermore, you should recollect the deities:

an11.11:8.2.pli: ‘santi devā cātumahārājikā, santi devā tāvatiṃsā, santi devā yāmā, santi devā tusitā, santi devā nimmānaratino, santi devā paranimmitavasavattino, santi devā brahmakāyikā, santi devā tatuttari.
an11.11:8.2.eng: ‘There are the gods of the four great kings, the gods of the thirty-three, the gods of Yama, the joyful gods, the gods who love to create, the gods who control what is created by others, the gods of the Divinity’s host, and gods even higher than these.

an11.11:8.3.pli: Yathārūpāya saddhāya samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tatthūpapannā, mayhampi tathārūpā saddhā saṃvijjati.
an11.11:8.3.eng: When those deities passed away from here, they were reborn there because of their faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom. I, too, have the same kind of faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.’

an11.11:8.4.pli: Yathārūpena sīlena samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tatthūpapannā, mayhampi tathārūpaṃ sīlaṃ saṃvijjati.

an11.11:8.5.pli: Yathārūpena sutena samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tatthūpapannā, mayhampi tathārūpaṃ sutaṃ saṃvijjati.

an11.11:8.6.pli: Yathārūpena cāgena samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tatthūpapannā, mayhampi tathārūpo cāgo saṃvijjati.

an11.11:8.7.pli: Yathārūpāya paññāya samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tatthūpapannā, mayhampi tathārūpā paññā saṃvijjatī’ti.

an11.11:8.8.pli: Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako attano ca tāsañca devatānaṃ saddhañca sīlañca sutañca cāgañca paññañca anussarati, nevassa tasmiṃ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti;
an11.11:8.8.eng: When a noble disciple recollects the faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom of both themselves and the deities their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion.

an11.11:8.9.pli: ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hoti devatā ārabbha.
an11.11:8.9.eng: At that time their mind is quite unswerving, based on the deities.

an11.11:8.10.pli: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.
an11.11:8.10.eng: A noble disciple whose mind is unswerving finds inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and finds joy connected with the teaching.

an11.11:8.11.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
an11.11:8.11.eng: When they’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when they’re blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

an11.11:8.12.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, mahānāma, ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotasamāpanno devatānussatiṃ bhāvetī”ti.
an11.11:8.12.eng: This is called a noble disciple who lives in balance among people who are unbalanced, and lives untroubled among people who are troubled. They’ve entered the stream of the teaching and developed the recollection of the deities.”

an11.118-165:0.4.eng: Untitled Discourses on Eye Consciousness, Etc.

an11.12:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
an11.12:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

an11.12:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena mahānāmo sakko gilānā vuṭṭhito hoti aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā.
an11.12:1.2.eng: Now at that time Mahānāma the Sakyan had recently recovered from an illness.

an11.12:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū bhagavato cīvarakammaṃ karonti:
an11.12:1.3.eng: At that time several mendicants were making a robe for the Buddha …

an11.12:2.1.eng: Mahānāma the Sakyan heard about this.

an11.12:2.4.pli: Atha kho mahānāmo sakko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho mahānāmo sakko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an11.12:2.4.eng: He went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an11.12:2.6.eng: several mendicants are making a robe for the Buddha, thinking that

an11.12:2.7.eng: when his robe was finished and the three months of the rains residence had passed the Buddha would set out wandering.

an11.12:2.8.pli: Tesaṃ no, bhante, nānāvihārehi viharataṃ kenassa vihārena vihātabban”ti?
an11.12:2.8.eng: Now, we spend our life in various ways. Which of these should we practice?”

an11.12:3.2.pli: Etaṃ kho, mahānāma, tumhākaṃ patirūpaṃ kulaputtānaṃ yaṃ tumhe tathāgataṃ upasaṅkamitvā puccheyyātha:
an11.12:3.2.eng: It’s appropriate that gentlemen such as you come to me and ask:

an11.12:3.3.pli: ‘tesaṃ no, bhante, nānāvihārehi viharataṃ kenassa vihārena vihātabban’ti?
an11.12:3.3.eng: ‘We spend our life in various ways. Which of these should we practice?’

an11.12:3.4.pli: Saddho kho, mahānāma, ārādhako hoti, no assaddho;
an11.12:3.4.eng: The faithful succeed, not the faithless.

an11.12:3.5.eng: The energetic succeed, not the lazy.

an11.12:3.6.eng: The mindful succeed, not the unmindful.

an11.12:3.7.eng: Those with immersion succeed, not those without immersion.

an11.12:3.8.eng: The wise succeed, not the witless.

an11.12:3.9.pli: Imesu kho tvaṃ, mahānāma, pañcasu dhammesu patiṭṭhāya cha dhamme uttari bhāveyyāsi.
an11.12:3.9.eng: When you’re grounded on these five things, go on to develop six further things.

an11.12:4.1.eng: Firstly, you should recollect the Realized One:

an11.12:4.2.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
an11.12:4.2.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

an11.12:4.3.pli: Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako tathāgataṃ anussarati, nevassa tasmiṃ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti;
an11.12:4.3.eng: When a noble disciple recollects the Realized One their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion.

an11.12:4.4.pli: ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hoti tathāgataṃ ārabbha.
an11.12:4.4.eng: At that time their mind is quite unswerving, based on the Realized One.

an11.12:4.5.pli: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.
an11.12:4.5.eng: A noble disciple whose mind is unswerving finds inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and finds joy connected with the teaching.

an11.12:4.6.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
an11.12:4.6.eng: When they’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when they’re blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

an11.12:4.7.pli: Imaṃ kho tvaṃ, mahānāma, buddhānussatiṃ gacchantopi bhāveyyāsi, ṭhitopi bhāveyyāsi, nisinnopi bhāveyyāsi, sayānopi bhāveyyāsi, kammantaṃ adhiṭṭhahantopi bhāveyyāsi, puttasambādhasayanaṃ ajjhāvasantopi bhāveyyāsi.
an11.12:4.7.eng: You should develop this recollection of the Buddha while walking, standing, sitting, lying down, while working, and while at home with your children.

an11.12:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ tvaṃ, mahānāma, dhammaṃ anussareyyāsi …pe…
an11.12:5.1.eng: Furthermore, you should recollect the teaching …

an11.12:5.7.pli: Yathārūpāya saddhāya samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tatthūpapannā, mayhampi tathārūpā saddhā saṃvijjati.

an11.12:5.11.pli: paññāya samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tatthūpapannā, mayhampi tathārūpā paññā saṃvijjatī’ti.

an11.12:5.12.pli: Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako attano ca tāsañca devatānaṃ saddhañca sīlañca sutañca cāgañca paññañca anussarati, nevassa tasmiṃ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti;
an11.12:5.12.eng: When a noble disciple recollects the faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom of both themselves and the deities their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion.

an11.12:5.13.pli: ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hoti devatā ārabbha.
an11.12:5.13.eng: At that time their mind is quite unswerving, based on the deities.

an11.12:5.14.pli: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.
an11.12:5.14.eng: A noble disciple whose mind is unswerving finds inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and finds joy connected with the teaching.

an11.12:5.15.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
an11.12:5.15.eng: When they’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when they’re blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

an11.12:5.16.pli: Imaṃ kho tvaṃ, mahānāma, devatānussatiṃ gacchantopi bhāveyyāsi, ṭhitopi bhāveyyāsi, nisinnopi bhāveyyāsi, sayānopi bhāveyyāsi, kammantaṃ adhiṭṭhahantopi bhāveyyāsi, puttasambādhasayanaṃ ajjhāvasantopi bhāveyyāsī”ti.
an11.12:5.16.eng: You should develop this recollection of the deities while walking, standing, sitting, lying down, while working, and while at home with your children.”
